thread.title: Ovies: Monday Night Football & Star Wars collide
thread.title_full: Ovies: Monday Night Football & Star Wars collide

title: Ovies: Monday Night Football & Star Wars collide
text:
Monday Night Football & Star Wars collide 
Posted 11:07 a.m. today Your friends e-mail addresses (comma separated): * Subject: * You must enter the characters with black color that stand out from the other characters By Joe Ovies 
Disney unleashed their corporate synergy force powers on ESPN, combining their biggest sports property with their biggest movie franchise to turn Monday Night Football into a cross-promotional vehicle for the final "Star Wars: The Force Awakens" trailer. 
It was brilliant move by Mickey Mouse. It was also unintentionally hilarious. 
For starters, never in a million years did ESPN's Mike Tirico envision his television career would include emcee for a science-fiction movie trailer. But there was Tirico, good company hype-man, reading his lines with a straight face. John Gruden, Tirico's Monday Night Football broadcast partner, probably wanted no part of the Star Wars hype and jumped to hyperspace out of the booth. 
Then there's Chris Berman, who I'm sure told ESPN executives no way in hell would he take a back seat to light sabers and X-Wings. The man is an institution in Bristol and he was going to get his dated NFL highlights in for the umpteenth time, darn it, and make those Star Wars nerds wait for their moment of glory. 
And finally, sometime around 10:15 p.m., Disney gave the people what they wanted. 
The hype worked, as Monday Night Football had a ratings spike before the Star Wars trailer debuted. #MNF viewership actually peaked *before* #StarWars trailer at 10:10pm: peak was 9:45-10pm, 11.7 rating in metered mkts, which is above avg. — Brian Stelter (@brianstelter) October 20, 2015 
On social media, searches for "football" and "Star Wars" revealed amusing results. Folks who had no interest in sports sat through a terrible first half between the New York Giants and Philadelphia Eagles. Football fans who didn't care about Star Wars suffered through all the promos and forced movie references. Meanwhile, a subsection of fans who enjoy both sports and Star Wars went all in with the jokes. "Aren’t you a little short for a quarterback …?” #StarWarsMNF pic.twitter.com/7Dew9YBeGg — Owen Good (@owengood) October 20, 2015 At least Star Wars fans are prepared for the terrible dialogue that is Chris Berman speaking.
